The β-H transfer of a propagating chain shows an unconventional polymerization behavior with single-site catalysts. In this work, we seek to address these challenges in the presence of different alkylaluminum cocatalysts. Adjusting the amount and type of cocatalyst in the polymerization process can affect molecular weight distribution (MWD) and chain ends formed via β-H transfer. The cocatalyst's elevated triethylelaluminum (TEA) by more than 50 % resulted in a drop in isoprene (IP) concentration, Mw, and activity, while pure TEA exhibited a smaller [C*]/[Zr] % than both pure Triisobutylaluminum (TIBA) and TIBA/TEA mixture. These results indicate that the type of alkylaluminum and its varying ratio affect the activation of metallocene catalysts. Secondly, this study also includes chain termination and transfer reactions and how comonomers participate in overcoming these issues. For this complicated process, we additionally performed the quench-labeling metal-polymer bonds technique (quantitative experiments (catalyst's active site)) leading to building a kinetic model that plays a significant role in mechanistic studies. The quantitative of active sites results indicate that the lower propagation rate constant (k p) was increased by nearly 20 % with TEA (25 %), and continuously increased with the TEA amount, meaning that TEA is a noticeable essential component in the cocatalyst for higher k p. The higher k pE and k pIP with TIBA might be associated with faster propagation and lower chain transfer reactions to Al−iBu and active centers and faster re-initiation of Al−iBu. The active center and 3,4 connections of IP are increased with increased TEA, meaning that the active site based on Al−Et bonds is facilitating more coordinated-to-IP through 3,4 connections. Finally, to clarify the impact of cocatalysts on MWD, a detailed theoretical splitting of the corresponding GPC was conducted. However, compared to PE MWD, TEA decreases the MWD of the polymers and becomes narrow. It is evident that introducing IP as a comonomer and TEA as a combined cocatalyst significantly reduces the chain transfer reaction that occurs during PE. Graphical Abstract Keywords Ethylene Metallocene Chain transfer Propagation Active centers Molecular weight distribution Data availability The authors do not have permission to share data. 1 Introduction Polyolefins (PE, PP, E/P, and E/a-olefins) are manufactured at an amazing annual scale exceeding 100 million tons, underscoring the profound societal importance of polymerization catalysis [1–6]. The field of polymer chemistry has witnessed remarkable advancements in recent years, with a growing emphasis on tailoring polymer properties for diverse industrial applications [7,8]. Polyolefin characteristics depend on numerous factors such as catalyst nature (single-site or multi-site) and nature of the monomer, comonomer content, Mw, MWD, and microstructure (Regio-stereoselectivity) of the polymers [8–12]. One of the key contributors to this progress has been the development of metallocene catalysts, particularly single-site symmetrical metallocene catalysts [13–15]. These catalyst systems have unparalleled control over polymerization processes, allowing for the precise synthesis of polymers with tailored structures and properties [16–19]. However, as with any revolutionary technology, challenges have emerged in their practical implementation, and one such challenge is the unconventional polymerization behavior observed in the presence of borate and alkyl aluminum additives. For example, E polymerization catalyzed by individual catalyst rac-Ethylenebis(indenyl)zirconium dichloride/MMAO produced a narrow MWD (Mw/Mn = 2) as predictable for single-site catalysts [20,21]. Fan et al., observed that the MWD of PE was broader, even bimodal when catalyzed by individual catalyst rac-Me2Si(2-Me-4-Ph-Ind)2ZrCl2/[Me2NPh][B(C6F5)4]/TIBA/TEA and rac-Me2Si(2-Me-4-Ph-Ind)2ZrCl2/[Ph3C] [B(C6F5)4]/TIBA/TEA, and recommended that the effects of metallocene catalyst on PE MWD were much more complicated [22,23]. In our previous work, we also noticed that the cocatalyst affected the PE propagation chain and produced the unsaturated chain ends formed via β-H transfer [24]. The catalyst rac-Me2Si(2-Me-4-Ph-Ind)2ZrCl2/[Ph3C] [B(C6F5)4]/TIBA/TEA β-H transfer of a propagating chain forms vinyl-ended polyethylene chain and showing an unconventional polymerization behavior. The synthesis of olefin polymerization by metallocene catalyst presented a precise control of propagating chain compared to Z-N and should produce one chain per catalyst. This intriguing issue has prompted extensive research efforts aimed at understanding and ultimately overcoming the complexities associated with PE-complicated MWD and the unsaturated chain ends formed via β-H transfer. [14,25,26] The unconventional behavior exhibited in such systems can lead to unpredictable polymerization outcomes, exposing the precision and reproducibility that are the hallmarks of metallocene catalysts. Therefore, a comprehensive investigation into the mechanisms governing this phenomenon is not only scientifically intriguing but also essential for advancing the practical utility of these catalysts in industrial polymerization processes. In this work, we are seeking to address the challenges posed by the unconventional polymerization behavior of single-site rac-Me2Si(2-Me-4-Ph-Ind)2ZrCl2 in the presence of different alkyl aluminum cocatalysts. For this purpose, a combination of borate and aluminum cocatalysts is utilized in the variation ratios. Secondly, adjusting the amount and type of cocatalyst in the polymerization process can affect MWD and chain ends that were formed via β-H transfer. We expected, to incorporate comonomers like α-olefin (Propylene or isoprene) can narrow the MWD. For this complicated process, we additionally performed the quench-labeling metal-polymer bonds method by using 2-thiophene carbonyl chloride (TPCC) as the quencher that selectively quenched the metal-polymer bonds, these quantitative experiments (catalyst's active site) will be helpful in kinetic and mechanistic studies. In addition, these kinetic studies also include chain termination and transfer reactions and how comonomers participate in overcoming these issues. By delving into the underlying mechanisms governing these interactions, reviewing recent research findings, and proposing potential strategies to mitigate these challenges, we aim to contribute to a deeper understanding of metallocene-based polymerization systems. The polymerization and catalyst dilution solvents were acquired from Jiangsu Yonghua Fine Chemical Co., Ltd., China, and subjected to reflux with sodium-benzophenone. 3 Polymerization The polymerization operations were conducted in a 100 mL Schlenk flask under an appropriately controlled atmosphere. In addition, the reactor was repeatedly filled with nitrogen and evacuated. The prescribed volume of solvent, E (1 MPa), isoprene, and TIBA were continuously introduced and run for 10 min. The copolymerization reaction significantly started by adding metallocene and borate. After the desired time, the copolymerization reaction was quenched with TPCC and run for 5 min. The cocatalyst [(Ph3C) B(C6F5)4] showed an ionic nature and had enough polarity. The solubility of [(Ph3C) B(C6F5)4] is more fantastic in toluene due to its aromatic nature and minor polarity. For a deeper understanding of the phenomena, Giuseppe et al. and our previous study deconvoluted the MWD curve of PE into 6–9 Flory components [24,46]. The typical MWD curves for PE and E/ip copolymers are shown in Fig. 2. In the curve of PE, six Flory components were observed when pure TIBA and TIBA/TEA = 75/25 were used as cocatalysts, while the number of Flory components was significantly increased when the TEA ratio was increased in the cocatalyst system. This means that TEA produced the polymer chain with low molecular weight. In contrast, in E/ip copolymers, the Flory components were significantly decreased when the TIBA ratio was reduced means that TIBA produced the polymer chain with higher Mw. The E/ip copolymer chains with higher Mw are formed by the catalytic active sites composed of contact ion pairs and exhibit faster chain propagation and slower chain transfer reactions. According to the available research, homogeneous metallocene catalysts may encompass various types of active centers, including contact ion pairs and loosely associated ion pairs. The significant contact ion pairs exhibited that the distance between the anion and cation is significantly shorter. In contrast, in loosely associated ion pairs metallocenium cation is importantly separated from the counter anion by a solvent and minimally influenced by the counter ion. So, the polymer chains that exhibited lower Mw were produced by those active centers composed of loose ion pairs, showing a faster rate of chain transfer reaction and a slower rate of chain propagation due to less steric hindrance of the counter ion. Similarly, loose ion pairs could not create enough steric hindrance when the TEA ratio is higher than TIBA, which leads to an increased rate of chain transfer reactions. The presence of active centers with loose ion pairs is significantly involved in the formation of PE and E/Ip polymers with low Mw. Compared to PE, in E/IP copolymers, the low Mw Flory components are notably lower, meaning that the addition of IP as a comonomer significantly reduced the chain transfer reaction. On the other hand, pure TEA showed a lower [C*]/[Zr] fraction than pure TIBA and TIBA/TEA mixture, demonstrating that the activation of metallocene catalyst influenced by the type of alkylaluminum and their different ratio. As illustrated in Table 1, the active center and 3,4 connections of IP are increased with increased TEA in the cocatalyst, while 1,4-insertions significantly decreased, meaning that the active site based on Al−Et bonds is facilitating more coordinated to IP through 3,4 connections. While active sites with Al−iBu bond showed a strong impact for both 3,4 connections and 1,4- insertions. However, the later active sites with Al−Et bonds failed to insert IP with 1,4- insertions, which means that pure Al−Et bonds only inserted the isoprene with 3,4 connections. In the initial level, with the increased TEA in the cocatalyst up to 50 %, the IP insertion was significantly increased and then started to drop, but k pE and k pIP progressively increased. It means that an increase in Al−Et bonds gradually increased the k pE and k pIP, and a higher amount of Al−Et bonds in the system and depressed the 1,4-insertions. The copolymer yield and active center ratio significantly decreased when the ratio of TEA increased in the cocatalyst system, but the k pE, k pIP values significantly increased. While, more than 50 % of TEA in cocatalyst shows a decreasing trend in the k p, which means that the TEA effect on active centers is powerful (see Fig. 3). In addition, the decrease in k p with a higher amount of TEA (50 %-100 of TEA) can be explained in terms of an increase in the proportion of dormant sites in the system. In contrast, the higher [C*]/[Zr] fraction value of metallocene/TEA than metallocene/TIBA might be explained by stronger alkylation power Al−Et than Al−iBu. Furthermore, this phenomenon also indicates that chain transfer reactions active centers more efficiently take place with Al−Et than with Al−iBu bond. After the activation of metallocene, [L2MTR]+[B(C6F5)4]−]− type ion pair has been recommended as a model of active centers [49,50]. According to this model, before the polymerization initiation, these ion pairs are required to undergo a dissociation process and leave space for monomer coordination. When TIBA is used, the alkylation of the metallocene catalyst produces L2MT(C3H9)2, and then with borate [L2MT(C3H9)]+[B(C6F5)4]−, the cation-anion distance in [L2MT(C3H9)]+[B(C6F5)4]− should be longer than [L2MT(C2H5)]+[B(C6F5)4]− making its initiation (insertion of the first monomer in MT−R bond) easier. This influence could be the main reason for the higher active center fraction of metallocene/TIBA than that of metallocene/TEA system. The higher k pE, and k P IP values of the copolymers with TIBA might be associated with faster propagation and lower chain transfer reactions to Al−iBu, and faster re-initiation. While in TEA, chain transfer with Zr−Et takes place, initiation of [L2MT(i-C2H5)]+[B(C6F5)4]− will be slower, and chain propagation will slow down, leading to lower k p value ( Fig. 4). In addition, TEA exhibits a greater degree of interruption in the chain propagation stages due to the presence of higher chain transfer reactions. Furthermore, as illustrated in Table 1 and Fig. 5, the k p value with pure TIBA is lower than TEA but TIBA produced a higher molecular weight (Mw). When the TEA level increased from 0 % to 25 % in the cocatalyst, the Flory components with larger Mw (A, B, and C) had less impact. Conversely, increasing the TEA concentration in the cocatalyst from 50–100 % resulted in a noticeable shift of the high Mw components towards the low Mw side (see Fig. 2). This observation indicates that the low Mw components (F∼H) are more affected by the Al-Et bond in the cocatalyst, whereas the high Mw components (A∼D) require a greater proportion of the Al-iBu bond in the cocatalyst to increase chain transfer. In addition, the differences in Mw can be further explained by the effectiveness of chain transfer with Al−iBu and Al−Et bonds and their different steric bulkiness. For example, metallocene/TIBA or a higher ratio of TIBA in the co-catalyst active centers exhibited bulky structure and tight ion pairs and produced copolymers with lower k p and higher Mw. The TIBA bulky structure and catalyst methyl and phenyl substituents could be responsible for its tighter ion pairs. However, in the literature, different steric hindrances (AlEt2(iBu) and AlEt(iBu)2) of TIBA and TEA may account for the various types of chain transfer efficiencies of Al−Et and Al−iBu bonds [24]. The TIBA-catalyzed E/ip copolymers exhibited lower k p and higher Mw, because Al−iBu presented a greater steric hindrance, resulting in a more sterically crowded environment around the active centers and a slower rate of chain transfer reactions. While in TEA, smaller alkyls like ethyl in Al−Et exhibited a smaller steric hindrance, which could be beneficial for fast coordination and initiation with the Al−Et bond resulting in higher k p , lower Mw, and border MWD (see Fig. 6). According to the literature, the metallocene with MAO and MMAO systems exhibited multiple types of active centers, for example, active centers exhibiting the contact ion pair were associated with significantly shorter cations and produced lower k p and higher molecular weight. Secondly, the active centers are composed of loosely associated ion pairs that have a significant difference and produce higher k p and lower molecular weight polymers. In addition, in loosely associated ion pairs metallocenium cation is significantly separated from the counter anion by a solvent and minimally influenced by the counter ion based on TEA. According to Zhang et al., the cocatalyst TIBA/TEA mixture significantly undergoes rapid alkyl exchanges to produce AlEt2(iBu) and AlEt(iBu)2 species. The TEA/TIBA mixture exhibited AlEt3, AlEt2(iBu), AlEt(iBu)2, and AliBu3, and the percentage of Al−Et bonds significantly increased with the increase of TEA [51]. However, if the TEA content in the cocatalyst is less than 50 %, the percentage of AlEt2(iBu) will be lower than that of AlEt(iBu)2. Additionally, the chain transfer reaction with AlEt(iBu)2 is similar to the chain transfer reaction with TIBA, perhaps because of the significant hindering caused by AlEt(iBu)2. The transfer of chains with AlEt(iBu)2 can take place efficiently in the active centers with a loose ion pair (resulting in low Mw polymers) because of the greater space available. Since AlEt2(iBu) is less bulky than AlEt(iBu)2, chain transfers with AlEt2(iBu) can take place efficiently in the active centers with tight ion pairs. This discussion helped us understand the complex alterations of PE and E/IP copolymers MWD with cocatalyst structure. The influence of alkylaluminum structure and ratio on propagation constant were significant. For example, we noticed that the lower k p value metallocene with 100 % TIBA was increased by nearly 20 % when a small amount of TEA (25 %) was added to the cocatalyst. Furthermore, the k p value continued to rise proportionally with the amount of TEA added. These findings indicate that TEA plays a crucial role as an indispensable component in the cocatalyst, contributing to the higher k p that is seen in the E/Ip copolymer system. However, a marginal decrease in the k p value was seen while utilizing pure TEA as the cocatalyst. Fan et al., found comparable findings in the homo polymerization of E and P. They explored that metallocene/borate/TIBA/TEA systems k p reduced by 60 % when pure TEA was used. We demonstrated in work, that the reduction in k p value was improved when TEA was used with TIBA. In addition, the [C*]/[Zr] and k p values were lower when 100 % TEA was used and importantly improved with increased of TIBA, leading to reduce the chain transfer reactions. The isoprene as a comonomer evidently increased the k p values and [C*]//Zr] fraction and reduced the chain transfer reaction in the PE. This means that TIBA/TEA and IP are obvious components for higher k p of the system. For deep insight into the mechanism of isoprene homo polymerization and their copolymerization with E, Zhaomin et al. performed DFT calculations and investigated the steric hindrance influences [52,53]. They observed that the less steric catalysts afford 1,4-isoprene insertion as a major component for chain transfer reactions in the growing polymer chain exhibiting a species that has enough space for β-hydrogen elimination. The resultant olefin/hydride species would be vulnerable to ligand substitution by an entering IP monomer, thereby causing chain termination/transfer reactions [54,55]. Regarding these possible chain termination and chain transfer reactions, the silicon bridge exhibits a greater steric hindrance due to its bulky Cp ligands that might prevent the β-hydrogen elimination. Therefore, we were expecting this catalyst system chain transfer reaction to be significantly difficult and show a living feature in the E-IP copolymerization. In the copolymerization of E/ip, we are exploring whether polymerization initiation takes place with E molecules or isoprene molecules. In this study, with the help of analysis based on MWD, active sites, and NMR, we obtained sufficient information capable of describing the E/ip copolymers process. According to the 1HNMR analysis, the peaks at 1.01–1.30 ppm represent the PE, while at 5.12 and 4.56 ppm present the sic/trans 1,4 and 3,4 insertion of IP. Owing higher steric hindrance of metallocene, compared to IP, E is a smaller molecule and coordinates to the metal center first and initiates the polymerization. In general, the cationic active metallocene alkyls are Lewis acids and exhibit a solid tendency to coordinate with olefin. E is a simple molecule, and the presence of the π-electron cloud makes E capable of donating electrons to Lewis acids, thereby acting as a Lewis base. On the other hand, IP is a larger molecule and can donate electrons due to the presence of its double bonds, the degree of its Lewis base properties is generally lower compared to ethylene because of its larger size and the presence of additional functional groups. However, in IP, the double bond at the 3,4 position has less steric hindrance and significantly propagates in the polymer chain first. So during the polymerization, the TIBA/TEA as cocatalyst increased the 3,4 insertions and reached a higher regioselectivity level. However, when the ratio of the TIBA/TEA was 25/75 and 0/100, the 1,4-IP connection significantly decreased and reached 0 %, meaning that pure TEA presented higher regioselectivity and only inserted IP with 3,4 connections. Similarly, at the ratio of TIBA/TEA 0/100 and 25/75, the AliBu3 and AlEt(iBu)2 stabilize the active species with the catalyst during the alkylation process and promote the isoprene insertion with 3,4 insertions and 1,4-IP connection. While TEA (AlEt3 and AlEt2(iBu), with a higher amount failed to contribute to the steric environment around the metal center and influence the stereochemistry of the E/IP polymerizations. Furthermore, the reactivity and selectivity of silicon-bridged metallocene toward E/IP copolymerization can be influenced by some other factors including the nature of the ligands attached to the metal centers and their electronic properties. The presence of methyl and phenyl groups in the ligands enhances the electron density around the zirconium atom, making it more electron-rich. This significant increase facilitates the coordination of isoprene to the metal center and promotes the insertion of isoprene into the growing polymer chain. In addition, these groups also contribute to the steric environment around the metal center, influencing the regioselectivity and stereochemistry of the E/IP polymerizations. Similarly, methyl and phenyl groups of the catalyst help stabilize the active species formed during the alkylation process with TEA and TIBA. When isoprene undergoes polymerization, the 3,4-insertion positions the double bond of isoprene in a conformation that minimizes steric hindrance and maximizes stability. In the 3,4-insertion, the newly added IP unit forms a stable tertiary carbon-carbon bond with the growing polymer chain. This tertiary carbon bond is more stable compared to other possible insertion positions due to the distribution of electron density and the absence of significant steric hindrance. Mean that the isoprene was inserted first through 3,4 connections (B), then 1,4 connections, which was increased with TEA amount (See Scheme 1). While the lower amount of TIBA assisted the 1,4 insertions due to its higher steric hindrance. In contrast, Fan et al. reported the Z-N catalyzed E/Ip copolymerization, they explored, that the first insertion of IP takes place through 1,2 connections due to the less steric hundreds of Z-N. We noticed that the active center and 3,4 connections of IP are increased with increased TEA in the cocatalyst, meaning that coordination of 3,4 connections of IP to the catalyst transition metal is preferable, and it could be dominant in the chain initiation during the metallocene catalyst system. According to literature, in polyisoprene or E/ip copolymers, the catalysts that are suffering in the insertion of trans-1,4-Ip if they are less sterically feature [56,57]. In the case of our metallocene, we yielded cis-1,4 minor and trans-1,4 as major products but both are less than 3,4 isoprene insertion. This specific insertion pattern aligns the resulting copolymer chains in a way that optimizes their mechanical properties, such as elasticity and resilience, making them well-suited for applications like synthetic rubber production. 6 Conclusion In this work, we addressed the challenges such as chain ends formed via β-H transfer and unconventional MWD behavior of metallocene in the presence of different alkyl aluminum cocatalysts. To execute this complicated process, we employed the quench-labeling technique for the quantitative experiments and data (catalyst's active site) provided significant information regarding unconventional MWD behavior and chain transfer reactions. Compared to PE bimodal MWD, in the E/Ip copolymers, the narrowness of the MWD indicates a considerable reduction in chain transfer reactions upon the addition of isoprene. The fraction of [C*]/[Zr] exceeds 70 % with pure TIBA, while with the mixture (TIBA/TEA from 75/25, 50/50, and 25/75), the active site gradually decreased and ultimately reached 54.94 %. This observation indicates that the activation of the metallocene catalyst is influenced by the mixture. We also observed that the lower k p value metallocene with TIBA was increased by nearly 20 % when a small amount of TEA (25 %) was added to the cocatalyst, and the k p value continued to rise proportionally with the amount of TEA. These findings indicate that TEA plays a crucial role as an indispensable component in the cocatalyst, contributing to the higher k p that seen in the E/Ip copolymer system. coredata.dc:description: The β-H transfer of a propagating chain shows an unconventional polymerization behavior with single-site catalysts. In this work, we seek to address these challenges in the presence of different alkylaluminum cocatalysts. Adjusting the amount and type of cocatalyst in the polymerization process can affect molecular weight distribution (MWD) and chain ends formed via β-H transfer. The cocatalyst's elevated triethylelaluminum (TEA) by more than 50 % resulted in a drop in isoprene (IP) concentration, Mw, and activity, while pure TEA exhibited a smaller [C*]/[Zr] % than both pure Triisobutylaluminum (TIBA) and TIBA/TEA mixture. These results indicate that the type of alkylaluminum and its varying ratio affect the activation of metallocene catalysts. Secondly, this study also includes chain termination and transfer reactions and how comonomers participate in overcoming these issues. For this complicated process, we additionally performed the quench-labeling metal-polymer bonds technique (quantitative experiments (catalyst's active site)) leading to building a kinetic model that plays a significant role in mechanistic studies. The quantitative of active sites results indicate that the lower propagation rate constant (k p) was increased by nearly 20 % with TEA (25 %), and continuously increased with the TEA amount, meaning that TEA is a noticeable essential component in the cocatalyst for higher k p. The higher k pE and k pIP with TIBA might be associated with faster propagation and lower chain transfer reactions to Al−iBu and active centers and faster re-initiation of Al−iBu. The active center and 3,4 connections of IP are increased with increased TEA, meaning that the active site based on Al−Et bonds is facilitating more coordinated-to-IP through 3,4 connections. Finally, to clarify the impact of cocatalysts on MWD, a detailed theoretical splitting of the corresponding GPC was conducted. However, compared to PE MWD, TEA decreases the MWD of the polymers and becomes narrow. It is evident that introducing IP as a comonomer and TEA as a combined cocatalyst significantly reduces the chain transfer reaction that occurs during PE.
